articles.headline: Vice C.E.O.’s Departure Signals Fallen Hopes for Digital Media
articles.snippet: Nancy Dubuc is leaving the media company, which is exploring a sale of some or all of the business, after nearly five years there.
articles.abstract: Nancy Dubuc is leaving the media company, which is exploring a sale of some or all of the business, after nearly five years there.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Vice Media named Nancy Dubuc as its new chief executive in 2018, her contract hinted at one of her missions. Sell the company — at the time a darling of the media industry — and she could cash in on a big stock grant, according to a copy of the contract obtained by The New York Times.

articles.headline: Russia, Ukraine and the West Vow to Fight On, in a War With No End in Sight
articles.snippet: Moscow and Kyiv face daunting challenges in moving forward, with no clear sense of what an attainable victory might look like.
articles.abstract: Moscow and Kyiv face daunting challenges in moving forward, with no clear sense of what an attainable victory might look like.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the one-year mark of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin and President Biden both insisted this week that they were committed to the fight. Mr. Putin prepared Russia for a long war to be waged “step by step,” while the American president said “we will not tire” in the quest to ensure a democratic Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Steven Erlanger and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Protests and Defiance Mark a Year of Russia’s War on Ukraine
articles.snippet: On the anniversary of the invasion, Volodymyr Zelensky held a marathon news conference and vowed victory if Ukraine’s allies remained united like a fist.
articles.abstract: On the anniversary of the invasion, Volodymyr Zelensky held a marathon news conference and vowed victory if Ukraine’s allies remained united like a fist.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine marked the anniversary of the Russian invasion on Friday with a show of defiance, as anti-Kremlin protests took place around the world and the United States made a significant commitment of new weaponry to the country.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: What You Need to Know for the 2023 Tax Season
articles.snippet: Doing taxes in 2023 feels a lot like it did before the pandemic. Still, there are some meaningful changes to keep in mind.
articles.abstract: Doing taxes in 2023 feels a lot like it did before the pandemic. Still, there are some meaningful changes to keep in mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 2023 tax filing season is probably most notable for what’s missing: After three years of stimulus payments and pandemic tax breaks, nearly all of those extra benefits have faded away — and tax refunds are likely to shrink as a result.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Their Hair Long and Flowing or in Ponytails, Women in Iran Flaunt Their Locks
articles.snippet: Defiant resistance to Iran’s mandatory hijab law has exploded across the country after nationwide protests that erupted last year.
articles.abstract: Defiant resistance to Iran’s mandatory hijab law has exploded across the country after nationwide protests that erupted last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: An engineer strode onstage at an event in Tehran, wearing tight pants and a stylish shirt, and clutching a microphone in one hand. Her long brown hair, tied in a ponytail, swung freely behind her, uncovered, in open defiance of Iran’s strict hijab law.

articles.headline: The Furniture Hustlers of Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: As tech companies cut costs and move to remote work, their left-behind office furniture has become part of a booming trade.
articles.abstract: As tech companies cut costs and move to remote work, their left-behind office furniture has become part of a booming trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brandi Susewitz touched the curved stitching on a pair of bright red Arne Jacobsen Egg Chairs and announced they were worth around $5,000 each. The chairs were in pristine condition, perched in the reception area of the software company Sitecore’s office in downtown San Francisco.

articles.headline: Alone and Exploited, Migrant Children Work Brutal Jobs Across the U.S.
articles.snippet: Arriving in record numbers, they’re ending up in dangerous jobs that violate child labor laws — including in factories that make products for well-known brands like Cheetos and Fruit of the Loom.
articles.abstract: Arriving in record numbers, they’re ending up in dangerous jobs that violate child labor laws — including in factories that make products for well-known brands like Cheetos and Fruit of the Loom.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was almost midnight in Grand Rapids, Mich., but inside the factory everything was bright. A conveyor belt carried bags of Cheerios past a cluster of young workers. One was 15-year-old Carolina Yoc, who came to the United States on her own last year to live with a relative she had never met.
articles.byline: By Hannah Dreier and Kirsten Luce

articles.headline: Desperate for Babies, China Races to Undo an Era of Birth Limits. Is It Too Late?
articles.snippet: A number of new incentives encouraging people to have children highlight the challenges China faces in trying to boost its declining birthrate.
articles.abstract: A number of new incentives encouraging people to have children highlight the challenges China faces in trying to boost its declining birthrate.
articles.lead_paragraph: In China, a country that limits most couples to three children, one province is making a bold pitch to try to get its citizens to procreate: have as many babies as you want, even if you are unmarried.
articles.byline: By Nicole Hong and Zixu Wang

articles.headline: War in Ukraine Has Changed Europe Forever
articles.snippet: No event has transformed the continent more profoundly since the end of the Cold War, and there is no going back now.
articles.abstract: No event has transformed the continent more profoundly since the end of the Cold War, and there is no going back now.
articles.lead_paragraph: HELSINKI — A year ago, the day Russia invaded Ukraine and set in motion a devastating European ground war, President Sauli Niinisto of Finland declared: “Now the masks are off. Only the cold face of war is visible.”

articles.headline: In Ukraine War, Talking About Peace Is a Fight of Its Own
articles.snippet: Russia and the West have argued for months about which side is more willing to negotiate, with the world as an audience.
articles.abstract: Russia and the West have argued for months about which side is more willing to negotiate, with the world as an audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the fight in Ukraine has dragged on for the past year, another battle has unfolded in parallel: a war of words between Russia and the West over who is more interested in ending the conflict peacefully.

articles.headline: Why Do A.I. Chatbots Tell Lies and Act Weird? Look in the Mirror.
articles.snippet: One of the pioneers of artificial intelligence argues that chatbots are often prodded into producing strange results by the people who are using them.
articles.abstract: One of the pioneers of artificial intelligence argues that chatbots are often prodded into producing strange results by the people who are using them.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Microsoft added a chatbot to its Bing search engine this month, people noticed it was offering up all sorts of bogus information about the Gap, Mexican nightlife and the singer Billie Eilish.

articles.headline: Lab Leak Most Likely Caused Pandemic, Energy Dept. Says
articles.snippet: The conclusion, which was made with “low confidence,” came as America’s intelligence agencies remained divided over the origins of the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: The conclusion, which was made with “low confidence,” came as America’s intelligence agencies remained divided over the origins of the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — New intelligence has prompted the Energy Department to conclude that an accidental laboratory leak in China most likely caused the coronavirus pandemic, though U.S. spy agencies remain divided over the origins of the virus, American officials said on Sunday.

articles.headline: What Layoffs? Many Employers Are Eager to Hang On to Workers.
articles.snippet: Despite interest rate increases meant to cool the labor market, companies outside the tech industry worry about having too few workers, not too many.
articles.abstract: Despite interest rate increases meant to cool the labor market, companies outside the tech industry worry about having too few workers, not too many.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the height of the pandemic, hungry and housebound customers clamored for Home Run Inn Pizza’s frozen thin-crust pies. The company did everything to oblige.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Indian Americans Rapidly Climbing Political Ranks
articles.snippet: The 2024 cycle reflects huge strides in representation: A decade ago, “it was inconceivable that someone named Raj Goyle — let alone Rajeev Goyle — would run for office in Wichita,” said Mr. Goyle, a former Kansas lawmaker.
articles.abstract: The 2024 cycle reflects huge strides in representation: A decade ago, “it was inconceivable that someone named Raj Goyle — let alone Rajeev Goyle — would run for office in Wichita,” said Mr. Goyle, a former Kansas lawmaker.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2013, the House of Representatives had a single Indian American member. Fewer than 10 Indian Americans were serving in state legislatures. None had been elected to the Senate. None had run for president. Despite being one of the largest immigrant groups in the United States, Americans of Indian descent were barely represented in politics.
articles.byline: By Maggie Astor and Jill Cowan

articles.headline: As Oil Companies Stay Lean, Workers Move to Renewable Energy
articles.snippet: Solar, wind, geothermal, battery and other alternative-energy businesses are adding workers from fossil fuel companies, where employment has fallen.
articles.abstract: Solar, wind, geothermal, battery and other alternative-energy businesses are adding workers from fossil fuel companies, where employment has fallen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emma McConville was thrilled when she landed a job as a geologist at Exxon Mobil in 2017. She was assigned to work on one of the company’s most exciting and lucrative projects, a giant oil field off Guyana.

articles.headline: Challenges to Student Loan Cancellation Reach Supreme Court
articles.snippet: Justices will hear arguments Tuesday on President Biden’s plan to forgive an estimated $400 billion in debt. Conservative states have called it an abuse of his authority.
articles.abstract: Justices will hear arguments Tuesday on President Biden’s plan to forgive an estimated $400 billion in debt. Conservative states have called it an abuse of his authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: In September, Jason Doresky received a $10,000 direct deposit from the Education Department. It was a refund for payments he had made voluntarily on his federal student loans since March 2020, when the government told borrowers that they could stop paying temporarily because of the pandemic.

articles.headline: U.S. Commandos Advise Somalis in Fight Against Qaeda Branch
articles.snippet: A campaign in the Horn of Africa is now the most active element in the “forever wars” the United States has waged since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
articles.abstract: A campaign in the Horn of Africa is now the most active element in the “forever wars” the United States has waged since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALEDOGLE, Somalia — The promise and perils of America’s counterterrorism campaign were on full display at a remote training base in central Somalia.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Diana Zeyneb Alhindawi

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Take Up Case on Fate of Consumer Watchdog
articles.snippet: A decision against the bureau could cast doubt on every rule and enforcement action the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has taken.
articles.abstract: A decision against the bureau could cast doubt on every rule and enforcement action the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has taken.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear a case that could hobble the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and advance a key project of the conservative legal movement: to limit the power of independent agencies.

articles.headline: Musk Claims Media Bias in Debate Over ‘Dilbert’ Creator’s Racist Rant
articles.snippet: The Twitter chief waded into a scandal involving the cartoonist Scott Adams, as Twitter undergoes layoffs and struggles to lure back advertisers.
articles.abstract: The Twitter chief waded into a scandal involving the cartoonist Scott Adams, as Twitter undergoes layoffs and struggles to lure back advertisers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall, shortly after completing his purchase of Twitter, Elon Musk sent a message to a skittish corporate community: Trust me.
articles.byline: By Lora Kelley, Michael M. Grynbaum and Tiffany Hsu
